channel.title: The New York Times Trends
channel.description: 用中文浏览纽约时报热门报道

item.title:
The Kremlin has forced Echo of Moscow, Russia’s flagship liberal radio station, to shut down.
The station was a symbol of freedom after the Soviet Union collapsed, and has now become an emblem of the crackdown on dissent amid Russia's invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/9NPa7rHRnb

France seized a yacht belonging to Igor Sechin, who runs the Russian state oil giant Rosneft and is a close associate of President Vladimir Putin, as part of sanctions imposed on Russia over the war in Ukraine.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/3nsFkMKBay

H&M Group, one of the biggest clothing sellers in the world, temporarily stopped all sales in Russia, the retailer said, joining a growing list of companies rethinking their ties to the country after its invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/OMguSwkIxI

The Jan. 6 panel said in a court filing that there was evidence to conclude that Donald Trump might have engaged in a criminal conspiracy to try to stay in office. https://t.co/usSZCVDW6R https://t.co/jxSWBulqH6

In Opinion
"The invasion of Ukraine is a waking nightmare, horrible and absurd. And it’s being done in our name," Alexey Kovalev, an editor at the independent Russian news outlet Meduza, writes in a guest essay. https://t.co/fwwN4veu3A

The EU is expected to grant temporary protection to all Ukrainians fleeing Russia’s invasion. Europe's embrace stands in stark contrast to 2015, when people fleeing conflict in the Middle East and Africa were met with violent anti-immigrant backlash. https://t.co/SeKrYew3oc
As Russian forces close in on Kyiv, life is being brought into the world in the makeshift maternity ward of a hospital basement. https://t.co/6sryM3mtPX https://t.co/0tG2q6FXzF

Autherine Lucy Foster, the first Black student at the University of Alabama, has died at 92. Her time there lasted only three days; attacked by mobs, she was suspended and then expelled. Today, a campus building is named in her honor. https://t.co/sKqm6qysZF

President Volodymyr Zelensky of Ukraine portrayed invading Russian troops as directionless, even as Russia captured the city of Kherson.
"They don't know why they are here," he said of Russian soldiers. https://t.co/lwNbJZPkB4 https://t.co/LSZAXtX7VV

Breaking News: Michael Madigan, who wielded power among Democrats in Illinois for decades, was indicted on federal racketeering charges and accused of using his office for personal gain. https://t.co/jfLFV3uw0R

The Ukrainian government has been receiving free assistance in its legal and public relations campaigns against Russia from influential Washington firms, and more offers of free help have been rolling in, according to people familiar with the arrangements. https://t.co/VahGRLN9Py

Senator Tim Kaine of Virginia, who said he still experiences mild symptoms of long Covid, introduced a new bill with Senators Tammy Duckworth of Illinois and Ed Markey of Massachusetts, that calls for expanding and accelerating research into long Covid. https://t.co/bJUr597GPt
Breaking News: In a court filing, the Jan. 6 panel said there was evidence to conclude that Donald Trump may have committed crimes to try to stay in office. https://t.co/PawwQom91U

Vladimir Potanin, one of the richest men in Russia and a Guggenheim Museum donor for decades, is stepping down as a museum trustee, the latest oligarch affected by widening outrage over the war in Ukraine. https://t.co/Knwgox7ici

As Russia’s war in Ukraine intensifies, about one-third of Russians appear to oppose the invasion, Denis Volkov of @levada_ru told @EllenBarryNYT. But that may not matter to the Kremlin. Listen to the conversation: https://t.co/dTlBxCyqW4 https://t.co/1G2M7NQpPH

The Justice Department announced a task force to go after billionaire oligarchs who have aided President Vladimir Putin in his invasion of Ukraine, part of an effort by the U.S. to seize and freeze the assets of those who have violated sanctions. https://t.co/DoWEiPk5UT

As many as 15,000 people, including many children, have taken refuge in the Kyiv subway system to escape bombing and artillery fire as Russian forces advance on Ukraine’s capital, according to officials in Kyiv. https://t.co/fyGnPUknJN https://t.co/Wbbsz90Kig

The Biden administration on Wednesday ramped up restrictions on exporting certain technologies to Russia and Belarus. They said it would degrade the ability to wage war on Ukraine and would prevent Belarus from channeling forbidden goods to Russia. https://t.co/JgPkfbNBgI

As many as 15,000 people, most of them women and children, have taken up residence in Kyiv’s subway system as Russian forces attack, Kyiv's mayor said Wednesday. And the subway is not the only subterranean refuge. https://t.co/Zh3jA4f6vc

Husbands comfort their wives. Nurses tend to newborns. A mother sees her baby for the first time.
As Russian forces close in on Kyiv, life is being brought into the world in the makeshift maternity ward of a hospital basement. https://t.co/oMczlt9I4t https://t.co/VACyy5YtXA
Prime Minister Boris Johnson on Wednesday faced pressure from lawmakers to take specific measures to expose the assets of Russia's oligarchs in Britain. https://t.co/FT1rHn7s2S

Russian soldiers, one holding grenades above his head, walked through an angry, shouting crowd in Konotop, Ukraine. In another video, the city's mayor asked the crowd to make a decision: Surrender or fight?
See the footage, verified by the New York Times: https://t.co/bGd7Z4lc4W

“It’s a sea change,” Anne-Claire Legendre, the spokeswoman for the French Foreign Ministry, said of the world's response to Russia's invasion of Ukraine. “A new world has defied Putin, the master of propaganda.” https://t.co/RBNbxXCBEq
Oracle, the enterprise software company, said Wednesday it had “suspended all operations” in Russia in response to the country’s invasion of Ukraine. https://t.co/oFvmIkiWU1

A missile struck a government building on Wednesday in Kharkiv, Ukraine’s second-largest city and a central target in Russia's invasion. Rescue workers pulled 10 people from the burning wreckage, the city’s emergency services agency said. https://t.co/dffEmFE4lv https://t.co/R1XcOIRyI9

The Dutch, Estonians, Poles, Latvians and also Czechs: In all, about 20 countries — most members of NATO and the EU, but not all — are funneling arms into Ukraine to fight off Russian invaders and arm an insurgency, if the war comes to that. https://t.co/djFlGPlPgY

Ukrainian families in Kyiv have fled to an underground subway station, where many of them have been living for about a week as Russian forces continue to attack and surround the capital.
Follow live updates from the ground. https://t.co/IMHikyhdFx https://t.co/Eohm01yJXm

Ukrainian security forces guard Maidan Square in Kyiv on Wednesday, as Russian forces continue to mass outside the city in what experts fear is an attempt to encircle the capital.
Follow live updates. https://t.co/PMRFRqpsy7 https://t.co/ebL2Xpu9ZP

The UN General Assembly adopted a resolution to condemn Russia’s invasion of Ukraine, with 141 countries voting in favor, five voting against and 35 abstaining. https://t.co/Tf36GzSSMY https://t.co/ZYykQYOHCD
Breaking News: Russia overtook the strategic hub of Kherson in southern Ukraine, making it the first major city to fall since the war began. https://t.co/CYXjDQNVkt

Russia’s invasion of Ukraine has prompted alarm in Eastern Europe, as President Vladimir Putin seeks to reclaim Russia’s sphere of influence.
“Nobody here trusted the Russians before and we certainly don’t trust them now,” one former Polish soldier said. https://t.co/YYVImVFDqF

Chinese officials told Russian officials in early February not to invade Ukraine before the end of the Winter Olympics in Beijing, according to senior Biden administration officials and a European official. https://t.co/I9FMwf4mEQ

Husbands comfort their wives. Nurses tend to newborns. A mother sees her baby for the first time.
As Russian forces close in on Kyiv, life is being brought into the world in the makeshift maternity ward of a hospital basement. https://t.co/xrSF2WuGaL https://t.co/kxykW7NOvP

The UN General Assembly will vote on Wednesday on a resolution condemning Russia for invading Ukraine and placing its nuclear defense on high alert. The resolution is highly symbolic as a measure of Russia’s isolation, though not legally binding. https://t.co/z1tXLyFCOV https://t.co/Y8cwgSKRUl

In Opinion
President Volodymyr Zelensky’s chief of staff, writing from a bunker in Ukraine with the president beside him, vowed to fight "to the last breath." https://t.co/Zjc2VF8Jvt
Breaking News: The soccer club Chelsea is for sale as Roman Abramovich, the Russian oligarch who owns the Premier League team, looks to shed assets. https://t.co/R2uxAunVlp

In Odessa, Ukraine’s biggest port city, people are building defenses as they brace for a Russian attack.
At the city’s tram authority rail yard, old steel rails are being sliced up and welded into barricades called “hedgehogs” to stop tanks. https://t.co/ckBjYLSZ44 https://t.co/7Jj9DY61Mc

Russian troops have “completely surrounded” the southern port city of Kherson as casualties mount and residents shelter in their homes, a Ukrainian official said. If captured, it would be the first major city to fall to Russia.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/Qe8Dau2Pr3

“It’s ruined,” Ilya, a 22-year-old who fled Kharkiv, said of the Ukrainian city that has been a target of Russia. “It is very bad there. They just ruined our city.”
He described a landscape of devastated buildings, failing electricity and constant fear. https://t.co/DdpEmcrcTw https://t.co/ocnNRtkJ7c

In Opinion
“I am writing this appeal from a bunker in the capital, with President Volodymyr Zelensky by my side,” says Andriy Yermak, head of the Presidential Office of Ukraine, in a guest essay. “Nothing less than our freedom — and yours — is at stake.” https://t.co/Cu4srFcrDW

Russia’s war on Ukraine has thrown a spotlight on oligarchs, most of whom amassed their wealth thanks to ties with President Vladimir Putin. Many have used London to hide or launder their fortunes, but now Britain is moving to plug embarrassing loopholes. https://t.co/GNOvP2udyR

A Ukrainian soldier was filmed reciting a Persian love poem on the eve of battle. Written by Hamid Mosadegh, it is called, “Who will tell you the news of my death?" https://t.co/CRQ0emjlFg https://t.co/VCnjtD9pEI
Boeing and Ford Motor, two major U.S. manufacturers, have suspended their business activities in Russia as the country escalated its war in Ukraine. https://t.co/Zq6PjBdYci

Following reports that Ukrainian border guards were hindering Africans trying to flee Russia’s invasion, Ukraine’s foreign minister, Dmytro Kuleba, said the government would try to “solve the problem.” https://t.co/TM5pHMJ6x0 https://t.co/rcvslBgekm
The mounting death toll for Russian troops in the war on Ukraine could damage any remaining domestic support that President Vladimir Putin has for the invasion. https://t.co/8Xn2A1tzSJ

The EU agreed on new sanctions against Belarus for aiding Russia in the invasion of Ukraine. They include a ban on valuable exports of potash, used for fertilizer, as well as timber, iron, steel, cement and tobacco.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/x5NlvzUQCc

Aleksei Navalny, the most prominent critic of President Vladimir Putin, called for Russians to protest the invasion of Ukraine. Russians “must, gritting our teeth and overcoming fear, come out and demand an end to the war,” he said.
Follow our updates. https://t.co/eMsUrTK3qB

The Russian military said it fully controlled Kherson, a strategic city in Ukraine. But the claim could not be immediately verified, and Ukrainian officials said that while Kherson was surrounded, the battle for it continued.
Follow live updates. https://t.co/rUNww2qEev

Across Ukraine, families are being forced to make split-second decisions in light of Russia’s invasion: to stay, flee or take up arms to defend their country.
"I am the mother of my son," one woman said. "And I don’t know if I will see him again or not." https://t.co/IeH1PwnhGO https://t.co/kdcTRMOspW

As dawn broke in Ukraine, blasts were reported across Kyiv and air-raid sirens blared in cities across the country. A convoy of Russian tanks and mechanized vehicles moved to encircle the capital in advance of what officials fear could be a brutal siege. https://t.co/ZusClmsVAT
